questions.text: A 22 y/o woman arrives at the clinic complaining of heavy menstrual flow and recurrent nosebleeds. Upon physical inspection, her arms and legs have several minor bruises. Coagulation studies show high BT, APTT, and normal PT. She is diagnosed with von Willibrand disease. Which type of vWD shows a decrease in binding between VWF and Gp 1b/9?
questions.explanation:
vWD type 1 (Option A)

vWD Type 2

vWD Type 3 (Option D)
  • Autosomal dominant.
  • The most common type.
  • Mild to moderate vWF deficiency.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • point substitutions prevent the vWF protein from maturing or cause it to leave the plasma quickly
  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Qualitative defect.


Types: 2A, 2B, 2M, 2N

  • 2A (Most common) - Decrease in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9 (Option B) missense mutations cause faulty multimer formation → the most active forms of vWF, i.e. large- and intermediate-sized multimers are absent.
  • 2B - Increase in binding between vWF and Gp1b/9 (Option C)
  • 2M - VWF dependant platelet adhesion is decreased. There is impairment of VWF binding to platelets. Type 2M VWD typically has mild to moderate mucocutaneous bleeding
  • 2N - There is marked decline in the binding affinity for factor VIII. The level of factor VIII is lower when compared to the VWF:Ag. This led to misdiagnosis as haemophilia A
  • Autosomal recessive.
  • Quantitative defect.
  • produced by frameshift mutations or deletions affecting both alleles (autosomal recessive), which produce little or no vWF.
  • Factor VIII levels are also lowered because vWF stabilizes factor VIII in the blood, and the resulting bleeding condition is severe.
